author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Amazon Prime Grubhub Deal: What to Know
description: A deal between Amazon and the food distribution service Grubhub includes free delivery for Prime members.
content: Under earnings pressure after a big loss last year, the food distribution company Grubhub struck a deal with Amazon on Wednesday, offering restaurant delivery services without a fee for Amazon Prime members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Jones
title: How Talking to the Dead Dislodged Some of My Sorrow
description: Voice mail helps a daughter cope with her mother’s death.
content: I began leaving voice-mail messages for my mother about a month after she died. It was February last year, during some of the darkest days of the pandemic for my family. My teenage daughters were mourning their grandmother while largely cut off from their friends and school. My husband and I were also struggling, drifting apart while cooped up in the same house together. And in my determination not to crumble in front of my girls when their worlds were already spinning out, I couldn’t, or wouldn’t, open the door for my own grief. It’s as if it were stuck deep in my chest, unable to find the space to surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
title: France, Hoping to Weather Energy Crisis, Will Renationalize Electricity Giant
description: The state already has a majority stake in France’s main electricity and nuclear company. The move reflected President Emmanuel Macron’s desire to champion economic and energy sovereignty.
content: PARIS — France said on Wednesday that it would renationalize its state-backed electricity giant to help ensure the country’s energy sovereignty as Europe faces a worsening energy crisis from Russia’s war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Derecho Brings Green Sky and ‘Tornado-Like’ Winds to South Dakota
description: Meteorologists recorded winds of up to 99 miles per hour in parts of the state, with minor damage reported.
content: South Dakotans are accustomed to the storms known as derechos — they’ve had two recently. What they’re not used to seeing is skies that turn green right before severe weather tears through the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Nakedness Is Everywhere in Fashion, Even the Heel of a Shoe
description: Four fake legs held up two real legs at Alaïa.
content: All fashion week, we will be spotlighting the small details we saw on the runways that surprised or delighted us: Bring on the portable fog machines and antique fork jewelry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth
title: A Brief Guide to the Wide, Wild World of Art Schools and Residencies
description: Thinking about applying? Not sure which route to take? Here’s an overview of 12 programs stretching from Frankfurt to Dakar to rural Wisconsin.
content: Future doctors are required to learn anatomy and much else. Lawyers must have a basic grasp of civil and criminal procedure and, in the United States, prove it by passing a bar exam. For professional artists, the path is less clear. Today, as the scholar Nicholas Houghton wrote in a 2016 paper on art school curriculums, “there are ever more things that could be taught without there being anything which has to be.” While particular skills — a mastery of perspective, say — may have been essential in some eras, in some places, artists now do anything and everything, from cooking food to social justice work to having specialists fabricate supersize sculptures for them and even, at least in the case of Sergio Muñoz Sarmiento, attending law school, as part of their practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Global oil prices dip below $100, a sign that recession fears are taking hold.
description: Oil prices have been slipping over the last two weeks, but the drop has accelerated in recent days.
content: HOUSTON — The global benchmark for oil dropped below $100 a barrel on Wednesday for the first time since late April as fears of a looming recession spread among traders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting on Majorca: A Stone Manor Mixing Spanish, French Styles
description: Unrelenting demand from foreign investors has drained the Spanish island’s inventory, spurring the government to take cooling measures.
content: This eight-bedroom stone manor house is in the town of Sóller, near the northwest coast of Majorca, one of Spain’s Balearic Islands in the heart of the Mediterranean Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Pyenson
title: Pass the Chowder, and the Curry: Jamaican Chefs Add to Cape Cod’s Culinary Delights
description: Thanks to Jamaican seasonal workers, the taste of Cape Cod now extends beyond the known lineup of Yankee favorites, to golden patties, jerk-rubbed meats and turmeric-rich curries.
content: At the Jerk Cafe, a storefront tucked into a strip mall in the Cape Cod village of South Yarmouth, Mass., sweet-smelling smoke greets guests as soon as they open the front door. So does the cafe’s proprietor, Glenroy Burke, who bounces around the wide-open kitchen stirring pots, tending the grill and plating dishes. “I don’t like to be hidden in the kitchen,” Mr. Burke said, who’s also known as “Chef Shrimpy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees’ Update on Aaron Judge: There Will Be No Updates
description: Hal Steinbrenner, the team’s managing general partner, said he, like Judge, did not want any contract-related distractions while the team pursued a championship. But he wouldn’t mind more pitching.
content: Wednesday was the midpoint of the Yankees’ 2022 season. Through 81 games, they not only had the best record (58-23) in Major League Baseball, but they also were on a pace to match the 1906 Chicago Cubs and the 2001 Seattle Mariners for the most wins (116) in a 162-game regular season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Witnesses in Young Thug Case Have Been Threatened, Prosecutors Say
description: Following a May indictment accusing the rapper and 27 others of gang-related crimes, defense lawyers must now withhold witnesses’ contact information from their clients.
content: ATLANTA — Citing “numerous threats to kill or harm witnesses,” prosecutors in the case against the rapper Young Thug and a group of his associates who are accused of being part of a violent street gang have secured an order that forces defense lawyers to withhold witnesses’ contact information from their clients, court documents show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: With Rising Book Bans, Librarians Have Come Under Attack
description: Caustic fights over which books belong on the shelves have put librarians at the center of a bitter and widening culture war.
content: Martha Hickson, a high school librarian in Annandale, N.J., heard last fall that some parents were going to call for her library to ban certain books. So at 7 p.m., when she and her husband would usually watch “Jeopardy!” she got comfortable in her recliner and turned on a livestream of the local school board meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: What happens next if Johnson quits?
description: If Boris Johnson resigns, here is what could happen next.
content: If Boris Johnson were to resign, there would not automatically be a general election to replace him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Eileen Sullivan
title: Disinformation Has Become Another Untouchable Problem in Washington
description: Numerous federal agencies agree that widely promoted falsehoods threaten the nation’s security. Doing something about them is another matter.
content: WASHINGTON — The memo that reached the top of the Department of Homeland Security in September could not have been clearer about its plan to create a board to monitor national security threats caused by the spread of dangerous disinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Bittle
title: How One Restaurateur Transformed America’s Energy Industry
description: Charif Souki’s longshot bet on liquid natural gas, or L.N.G., paid off handsomely — and turned the United States into a leading fossil-fuel exporter.
content: If you wanted to tell the story of how the United States became one the world’s largest exporters of fossil fuels, you could start in the Middle Devonian period, around 400 million years ago, when a warm inland sea dense with primitive aquatic organisms covered parts of the northeastern United States and Appalachia; you could explain that as these creatures lived, reproduced and died, their remains settled on the ocean floor and were compressed beneath layers of sedimentary rock, until eventually they transformed into a gas trapped thousands of feet below what is now Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: Descended From Shamans and Ghost Whisperers
description: In her debut memoir, Ingrid Rojas Contreras summons stories from the living and the dead to connect her own experiences to those of her Colombian ancestors.
content: In 2012, Ingrid Rojas Contreras traveled to her mother’s hometown, Ocaña, Colombia, to exhume her grandfather Nono’s body at the request of several spirits who family members said had appeared to them in dreams. Researching her ancestry while there, she picked up a book so old that it disintegrated in her hands, leaving nothing but dust. “It’s like I watched history erase itself,” she despaired, reflecting on her failed hunt for family documents. Her mother laughed in her face. “Who do you think we are,” she scoffed, “the type of people to be in the public record?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: What’s the Most Curious and Fraught Job in Tennis?
description: Coaches in tennis have one of the odder existences in sports. Some players go for long periods without even using one, and others change coaches like socks.
content: It was, by the usually secretive standards of coach-player relationships in tennis, an unorthodox move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Sajid Javid says ‘the problem starts at the top’ as more Conservatives call for Johnson to quit.
description: In explaining to Parliament why he stepped down from Boris Johnson’s government, Mr. Javid said, “Treading the tightrope between loyalty and integrity has become impossible in recent months.”
content: Sajid Javid, whose decision to step down as health minister on Tuesday helped plunge Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain into further political tumult, said in Parliament on Wednesday that he was “deeply concerned” about how the next generation would see Mr. Johnson’s Conservative Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Steam Deck Review: A Game Console for the Quintessential Gamer
description: This new hand-held gaming device by Valve is lots of fun. But perhaps not as much if you’re a casual gamer.
content: There’s a new hard-to-get game console this year that’s not a PlayStation or an Xbox. It’s sold online only. Most casual gamers probably haven’t heard of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: The Rise of the Far-Right Latina
description: Representative Mayra Flores is one of three Republican Latinas vying to transform South Texas politics by shunning moderates and often embracing the extreme.
content: WASHINGTON — For years, Texas Republicans tried to win the Hispanic vote using a Bush-era brand of compassionate conservatism. The idea was that a moderate’s touch and a softer rhetoric on immigration were key to making inroads with Hispanic voters, particularly in Democratic strongholds along the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: U.K. Museums Face a Sticky Problem From Climate Protests
description: Activists are gluing themselves to the frames of iconic paintings. They say it does not matter whether their actions are popular — only whether they are noticed.
content: LONDON — Room 34 of the National Gallery in London was jammed with tourists Monday afternoon studying the masterpieces of British art on its walls, including J.M.W. Turner’s “The Fighting Temeraire,” which depicts a warship being towed to a breaker’s yard, and George Stubbs’s “Whistlejacket,” a huge painting of a horse rearing skyward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Mohammad Barkindo, OPEC’s top official, dies.
description: As secretary general, he steered the oil producers group in a turbulent era.
content: A prominent figure in the international oil industry, Mohammad Sanusi Barkindo, the secretary general of OPEC, died Tuesday in Nigeria, his home country, according to the oil producers group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: When Paying Dues Doesn’t Pay the Rent, How Does the Theater Survive?
description: Frank talk about salaries and the end of unpaid internships are positive steps, but the cost may be fewer opportunities to learn the ropes.
content: A woman who has been working for about 16 years in a costume shop at a midsize theater in a midsize city in the Midwest agreed to discuss her job. A typical 40-hour week finds her cutting, draping, patterning, tailoring, altering, stitching, dyeing, distressing, repairing and “whatever else comes up.” The pay is $18.64 an hour, but only during the theater’s nine-month season. During her three-month furlough, she collects unemployment and goes without health insurance, “praying to Baby Jesus,” she told me, “I don’t hurt myself over the summer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Nadhim Zahawi, the newly appointed chancellor, affirms his support for the prime minister.
description: Mr. Zahawi, Britain’s new top finance minister, defended Boris Johnson on Wednesday’s morning news shows, but said that his focus was on tackling inflation.
content: The newly appointed chancellor of the Exchequer, Nadhim Zahawi, came to the defense of Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain as he made the rounds on the morning television circuit on Wednesday, only hours after succeeding the recently resigned Rishi Sunak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Jake Paul Gets New Opponent After Tommy Fury’s Travel Troubles
description: Fury was denied entry to the United States as his family faces questions about connections to Daniel Kinahan, a promoter who the U.S. says is also the head of a drug cartel.
content: For the second time in eight months, a Jake Paul and Tommy Fury fight has been canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Three War Scenarios
description: And what will influence the outcome in Ukraine.
content: Avril Haines, the U.S. director of national intelligence, recently outlined three plausible scenarios in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: How War in Ukraine Roiled Russia’s ‘Coolest Company’
description: The decline of Yandex, the Russian version of Google, is emblematic of the economic and cultural troubles spawned by the invasion.
content: What a difference a war makes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Jerry Harris Sentenced to 12 Years for Sex Crimes Involving Minors
description: Mr. Harris, who shot to reality-TV fame in the Netflix documentary series “Cheer,” had pleaded guilty to federal charges related to soliciting child sexual abuse imagery and illegal sexual conduct with a minor.
content: A judge in Chicago sentenced Jerry Harris, the Navarro College cheerleader who became a breakout star of the Netflix documentary series “Cheer,” to 12 years in prison on Wednesday on guilty pleas to two of seven federal charges related to sex crimes involving minors in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: A Darkened Outlook for Britain
description: The political instability comes as Britain gears up for a difficult summer, amid surging energy prices and labor shortages.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s political position continued to be on the rocks this morning as several lower-ranking ministers’ resignations followed two shattering defections last night. The moves raise questions about how long he can cling to power and what a change in leadership would look like for the British economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Chanel and Armani: Playing for Keeps in a Barbie World
description: Plus Paco Rabanne’s plastic-fantastic dystopian dressing.
content: PARIS — These days it’s hard to see any bright pink item of clothing and not think: “Barbie!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Ethnic Killings in Ethiopia Add to Crisis
description: Allegations of a second recent ethnic massacre in the restive region of Oromia further destabilize a country already coping with civil war in a northern region.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Crises are multiplying across Ethiopia: hunger from the worst drought in four decades, skirmishes with neighboring Sudan and a brutal 20-month-long civil war in the northern region of Tigray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Kyrgios, Under a Hotter Spotlight, Stays Quiet and Wins Again
description: A day after the emergence of allegations that he assaulted a former girlfriend, Kyrgios found a way to advance to a Wimbledon semifinal but declined to address the accusations afterward.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — The tennis career of Nick Kyrgios has long been an exercise in torture and turmoil, featuring battles with tennis officials, rivals, the news media, alcohol and a psyche that never seems at peace, even when he swears it is. Kyrgios said he contemplated suicide in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Knicks Stumbled Last Season. Here’s How They Can Recover.
description: With free agency beginning, the Knicks have several options to build on what’s working and to move on from what is not.
content: Good news for Knicks fans: The franchise has lured one of the best free agents, a rare occurrence for the team this century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: The Quest by Circadian Medicine to Make the Most of Our Body Clocks
description: Researchers are trying to figure out the right hour of the day to do everything. Can their studies sync us up with better health?
content: “Time,” when we give it any thought, tends to strike us as extrinsic, a feature of our landscape: We track our passage through it as if traversing an invisible geography, our progress charted by wristwatch, clock, calendar. Humans didn’t invent time, of course, but you might reasonably argue that because we invented the units we use to keep track of it — hours, minutes, seconds — we have every right to tinker with them when we want to. This, at least, was the position the Senate took on March 15, when in a surprise, and surprisingly uncontested, vote it passed the Sunshine Protection Act. The new law would, if the House concurs and the president signs, make daylight saving time permanent, beginning on Nov. 5, 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Clare Toeniskoetter, Eric Krupke, Carlos Prieto, Will Reid, John Ketchum, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: How Brittney Griner Became a Political Pawn
description: Growing public pressure to free the W.N.B.A. star, who has been detained in Russia for months, comes with risks.
content: Brittney Griner, the American W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia since February, recently sent a letter to President Biden. “I’m terrified I might be here forever,” she wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $830,000 Homes in Ohio, Connecticut and the District of Columbia
description: A Spanish-style house in Oakwood, a 1764 Colonial in Lyme and a three-bedroom rowhouse in Washington.
content: In the years after the 1913 flood in Dayton, Ohio, many wealthy residents made their way to nearby Oakwood, where builders advertised lots as occupying higher ground than those in Dayton. This house is about half a mile from Hawthorn Hill, the former home of the inventor Orville Wright, and from the University of Dayton, a private Catholic school with around 12,000 students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: A Great Biscuit Is a Miracle of Care
description: Savory with kimchi and Cheddar, these biscuits taste like an act of generosity.
content: A good biscuit is a miracle. Its own holy ritual and a hangover cure-all. No matter how foolproof your recipe may be, or how many generations have passed it down, the moment a biscuit departs an oven follows a familiar pattern: expectation, followed by suspense, before the elation payoff. Success is immediately recognizable, weightless in your hands. You know it when you see it. You remember it when you taste it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: The subvariants of summer
description: BA.4 and BA.5 are taking over.
content: The troublesome hits just keep coming from the Omicron strains — and each sequel is more contagious than the last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and April Rubin
title: Parents Sue TikTok, Saying Children Died After Viewing ‘Blackout Challenge’
description: The suit, involving girls ages 8 and 9, claims TikTok knew or should have known that its product was “addictive” and was directing children to dangerous content.
content: The parents of two girls who said their children died as a result of a “blackout challenge” on TikTok are suing the company, claiming its algorithm intentionally served the children dangerous content that led to their deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Bird Flu May Have Caused Seal Strandings
description: Unusually high numbers of the marine mammals were found stranded in the last two months along Maine’s coast. Samples from four seals tested positive for highly pathogenic avian influenza.
content: The highly pathogenic avian influenza strain that has whipped through flocks of domestic poultry and wild birds this year may also be to blame for a spike in seal strandings in Maine, U.S. officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Megan Specia
title: Ukraine’s Herculean Task: Helping Millions Whose Homes Are in Ruins or Russia’s Hands
description: Millions of Ukrainians have fled their homes as Russia has slowly advanced in the east. Many may not have a home to go back to when the war is over.
content: LONDON — When she fled her home in eastern Ukraine, Hanna Obuzhevanna, 71, gave her keys to her neighbor to water the blooming cyclamen on her balcony, thinking she’d be back in just a few weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Bryannita Nicholson testified that she drove Eric R. Holder Jr. to and from the scene of the crime.
description: Bryannita Nicholson, who had been casually seeing the defendant, Eric R. Holder Jr., testified that she had driven him to and from the scene of the shooting, providing one of the prosecution’s key accounts of the episode.
content: Bryannita Nicholson, who had been casually seeing the defendant, Eric R. Holder Jr., testified that she had driven him to and from the scene of the shooting, providing one of the prosecution’s key accounts of the episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Shock resignations in the British government.
content: Boris Johnson, the British prime minister, is battling for his political survival after the bombshell resignations yesterday of two top cabinet officers: Rishi Sunak, the chancellor of the Exchequer, and Sajid Javid, the health secretary. In the hours that followed, Alex Chalk, the solicitor general, and several people in junior government posts also quit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Murray
title: Americans Are Losing Their Right to Not Conform
description: The freedom to define oneself has deep roots in the American traditions of pluralism and independence.
content: On June 24 the Supreme Court laid waste to Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Casey on the grounds that the right to an abortion is not enumerated in the Constitution and is not deeply rooted in the history and traditions of the United States. As many commentators have noted, similar objections could be lodged against precedents like Griswold v. Connecticut, Lawrence v. Texas and Obergefell v. Hodges, which recognize constitutional protections for contraception, sex and marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Steve Ballmer Is Building a ‘Moneyball’ for Government
description: The former Microsoft chief executive, N.B.A. franchise owner and self-professed data nerd has big plans for his young nonprofit.
content: When Steve Ballmer retired from Microsoft in 2014, his wife, Connie Snyder, informed him his next job would be to help run the family philanthropy, which fosters upward economic mobility among children from lower-income families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Offers Women Perks for Having Babies. Single Moms Don’t Qualify.
description: Beijing is giving incentives to stem a demographic crisis, but its control over childbirth and its suppression of women’s rights are making it difficult for some aspiring parents to start a family.
content: When Chan Zhang heard about the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, she was baffled that Americans were still arguing over abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Thursday Briefing: War Displaces Millions of Ukrainians
description: Also, Boris Johnson battles to keep his job and Europe labels gas and nuclear energy “green.”
content: An estimated third of Ukraine’s population has been forced from home since Russia invaded in February, including an often unseen group of more than six million people who have been displaced within the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Parents of 8-Year-Old Were Accused of Her Murder. Now, So Are 12 More People.
description: Elizabeth Struhs of Queensland, Australia, died in January because, according to the police, she was denied medical care.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The police have charged 12 members of a religious group with murder in connection with the death of Elizabeth Struhs, 8, of Queensland state several months ago. The police say she was denied care over a period of days for an underlying medical condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Former President of U.S.A. Softball Accused of Abusing Minors
description: The Sacramento County Sheriff’s Office said the allegations were not related to the softball federation itself.
content: The former president of U.S.A. Softball, John Gouveia, was arrested in April and charged with a number of sex acts with minors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Malinowski
title: A Viable Third Party Is Coming, and It’s Starting With a New Jersey Lawsuit
description: A way for dismayed voters in the middle to get a voice.
content: On June 7, I won the Democratic Party primary in New Jersey’s Seventh Congressional District, on my way to what I hope will be my third term in the House. The same day, I also accepted the nomination of the new Moderate Party, formed substantially by state Republicans fed up with the extremism of a party led by Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Daily’ podcast looks at Brittney Griner’s detention in Russia.
description: In a new episode of “The Daily” podcast, Michael Crowley, a diplomatic correspondent for The New York Times, discusses the case of Brittney Griner, the American W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia since February.
content: In a new episode of “The Daily” podcast, Michael Crowley, a diplomatic correspondent for The New York Times, discusses the case of Brittney Griner, the American W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia since February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli and Jill Cowan
title: The jury has reached a verdict in the trial of Eric R. Holder Jr., who is accused of killing Nipsey Hussle.
description: The jury has reached a verdict in the trial of Eric R. Holder Jr., who was accused of murder in the 2019 shooting death of the Los Angeles-based rapper Nipsey Hussle, according to court officials.
content: The jury has reached a verdict in the trial of Eric R. Holder Jr., who was accused of murder in the 2019 shooting death of the Los Angeles-based rapper Nipsey Hussle, according to court officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Who are the contenders to lead the Conservative Party if Johnson resigns?
description: A small group is stepping to center stage as Britain’s political crisis intensifies, including the rival Boris Johnson beat last time.
content: As Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced rapidly mounting pressure from members of his own party to resign on Wednesday, the spotlight turned to who might succeed him as the leader of the Conservatives and the head of the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: The battlefields of eastern Ukraine are largely abandoned fields and streets.
description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign to capture Ukraine’s mineral-rich Donbas region was justified as a quest to protect the area’s Russian-speaking people. But only a fraction of them have stuck around as the Russian Army sweeps in.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign to capture Ukraine’s mineral-rich Donbas region was justified as a quest to protect the area’s Russian-speaking people. But only a fraction of them have stuck around as the Russian Army sweeps in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Fights to Hold Power After 2 Top Ministers Jump Ship
description: Two top cabinet members resigned from the scandal-scarred British prime minister’s government. Some wondered if the master of political survival could pull off another save.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain suffered a potentially lethal political blow on Tuesday when two of his most senior ministers quit in an apparently coordinated rebellion against his scandal-tainted leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: White House Communications Director Plans to Step Down
description: Kate Bedingfield will be the latest senior adviser to leave the Biden administration, whose messaging has faced growing criticism from Democrats.
content: WASHINGTON — Kate Bedingfield, the White House communications director, will step down from her position this summer, White House aides said on Wednesday, marking the latest departure of a senior adviser from the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed officials, spooked by data, fretted in June about inflation becoming entrenched.
description: Central bankers raised rates by the most since 1994 last month, and minutes from the gathering explained their logic.
content: Federal Reserve officials made their biggest interest rate increase since 1994 at their June meeting, after incoming inflation data spooked them, minutes from the meeting showed, with policymakers expressing concern that stubbornly persistent price pressures posed a “significant risk” of becoming a more permanent feature of the economy if the central bank did not act decisively.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Next Front Line in the Abortion Wars: State Supreme Courts
description: Court challenges to sweeping rollbacks of abortion rights must go through state supreme courts, many of which have been shaped by years of conservative activism.
content: WASHINGTON — Fresh from the political thicket of the United States Supreme Court, the struggle over abortion is now moving to venues that are poised to become the next front line in the country’s partisan warfare: state supreme courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Cancer Drug Greatly Reduces Deaths in Hospitalized Covid Patients
description: A new study found that sabizabulin reduced the risk of death by 55 percent, but some experts were cautious about overinterpreting the results.
content: An experimental drug initially developed to fight cancer cut the risk of death for people hospitalized with Covid by half, according to a study published on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meredith Mendelsohn
title: In Newport, Artists Turn Tables on the Gilded Age
description: In historic mansions where Sargent and Boldini reigned, a new generation of portraitists unites against the Old Guard for a summer show.
content: NEWPORT, R.I. — When visitors tour Stanford White’s Rosecliff this summer, one of the storied historical mansions where HBO’s “The Gilded Age” is filmed, they will find, among the antique heirlooms, a freshly painted life-size portrait of a woman wearing a casual gray pantsuit, a leopard-patterned fedora, and dark sunglasses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: With infections surging, Cyprus reinstates an indoor mask mandate.
description: The mandate will be enforced with spot inspections and fines of up to 300 euros ($305) for violators.
content: Bucking a global trend away from mandatory pandemic safety measures, Cyprus said on Wednesday that face masks would once again be required in indoor public settings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Tobias Kratzer Is Leading Opera’s Next Generation of Directors
description: With concurrent productions in France that are fresh yet faithful, Kratzer is “renewing opera, but renewing it intelligently,” says one colleague.
content: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — Scan the programming of Europe’s biggest opera houses, and you’ll see familiar names among the directors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: The Strident Writings of a Young Blake Masters Dog His Senate Run
description: As a Stanford student in 2007, the Arizona candidate, now 35, chose a CrossFit chat room to express his opposition to U.S. involvement in World War II and downplay Al Qaeda as a threat to Americans.
content: Blake Masters, a Republican candidate for the Senate in Arizona who won the endorsement of former President Donald J. Trump, has been dogged by a trail of youthful writings in which he lamented the entry of the United States into the First and Second World Wars, approvingly quoted a Nazi war criminal and pushed an isolationism that extended beyond even Mr. Trump’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Angel
title: Gardiner, N.Y.: Open Space and Mountain Views in Ulster County
description: The 50-mile Shawangunk Ridge is just one of the reasons New Yorkers are flocking to this Ulster County town, which is also prized for its wide-open spaces.
content: When Laura Phillips was planning her retirement after 30 years of teaching art to elementary school students and living in Seaford, N.Y., on Long Island, she and her husband started looking for a more tranquil place to live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: What are the symptoms of an infection with BA.4 and BA.5?
description: BA.5 has become dominant in the U.S.
content: In June, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that the Omicron subvariants BA.4 and BA.5 had become dominant in the U.S. The agency revised that statement on July 5 to say that BA.5 made up over half of new cases in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Global factors outweigh British political turmoil in the financial markets.
description: The long-running trends of rising inflation, worsening energy security and a weakening growth outlook are overshadowing the sudden political upheaval.
content: On Wednesday, as London’s financial markets reopened after the resignations of senior ministers put Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s tenure in doubt, Britain’s benchmark stock market index rose more than 1 percent, alongside increases in other European markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: The Real Reason the Minions Have Taken Over the World
description: Wordless, antic, physical: The film franchise’s comedy is nothing like prevailing family entertainment, and that’s a good thing.
content: Early one Saturday morning in the summer of 2015, I attended a press screening of an animated film with a few other critics and a lot of happy families. Before the film began, the studio played a trailer for “Minions,” Universal’s spinoff based on characters from its popular series “Despicable Me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: A Core Ritual Returns: Twice-Weekly Alternate-Side Parking
description: In New York, “your life revolves around alternate-side parking,” one driver lamented.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at the return of twice-a-week alternate-side parking for drivers in Manhattan, the Bronx and much of the rest of the city. And we’ll eavesdrop on one awe-struck but ambivalent fireworks-watching party on Brooklyn’s waterfront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Moves Toward Another Big Rate Increase as Inflation Lingers
description: As the Federal Reserve battles rapid inflation, officials are likely to stay on an aggressive path even as signs of economic cooling emerge.
content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, determined to choke off rapid inflation before it becomes a permanent feature of the American economy, is steering toward another three-quarter-point interest rate increase later this month even as the economy shows early signs of slowing and recession fears mount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The Academy Museum Names Jacqueline Stewart as New Leader
description: The film historian and preservationist specializes in Black cinema and silent movies. She had been serving as the institution’s chief artistic and programming officer.
content: The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures on Wednesday named Jacqueline Stewart, a film scholar who worked to make the long-delayed project a reality, as its new director and president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Amazon strikes a deal with Grubhub as the food-delivery business struggles.
description: The e-commerce giant could take a stake in Grubhub, which is under pressure as delivery demand falls, labor shortages bite and new regulations reduce profits.
content: Financial turmoil in the food-delivery industry is presenting new opportunities for Amazon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Kehlmann
title: Read Your Way Through Berlin
description: The German author Daniel Kehlmann, most recently of the novel “Tyll,” recommends books that explore the city’s painful past and dynamic present.
content: Berlin is not pretty. You should know that beforehand. You don’t come here for the beautiful architecture of an old European city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Johnson follows a familiar playbook in his response to the latest scandal.
description: The British prime minister’s blueprint for dealing with a crisis, his critics say, almost never begins, and rarely ends, with simply telling the truth.
content: This latest scandal, over a deputy whip in Parliament accused of sexual misconduct, is just one in a long, wearyingly similar series of self-inflicted troubles to befall Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Six Million Uprooted
description: Ukraine faces a humanitarian crisis from mass displacement.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Democrats Offer Plan to Cut Drug Costs, Seeking Climate and Tax Deal
description: The drug-pricing plan was negotiated with Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, but Democrats remain short of agreement on what else would be included in any domestic policy package.
content: WASHINGTON — Top Senate Democrats on Wednesday released an updated plan aimed at lowering the cost of prescription drugs, signaling progress on a crucial piece of their bid to salvage some of President Biden’s stalled social safety net, climate and tax bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: Lesley Gore’s Archive, Open to All, Arrives at the New York Public Library
description: The collection, which includes family photos, scrapbook pages and annotated music, traces the singer’s arc from releasing bubble gum hits to creating a powerful feminist statement.
content: As a teenage singer in the 1960s who fit the all-American girl mold, Lesley Gore may have seemed like an unlikely figure to carve out a lasting legacy of feminist resilience and independence. The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts has now made the musician’s archive available for anyone interested in her artistic evolution, giving fans a chance to browse through notated music sheets and an unfinished memoir.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Do It, I Dare You.’
description: Step inside the secret, beautiful world of a nanny in New York City and his tiny companion.
content: In his early 20s, Kevin Renn moved to New York City with dreams of making it as a playwright. When money got tight, he decided to fall back on a familiar option: babysitting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Millman
title: Republicans May Have Set Themselves Up for a Showdown With the Supreme Court
description: Two conservative critiques of the administrative state are in contradiction with each other.
content: Last week’s decision in West Virginia v. Environmental Protection Agency limiting the E.P.A.’s ability to regulate a shift to a less carbon-intensive economy should have surprised no one familiar with conservative complaints about the administrative state. The alphabet soup of federal executive branch agencies — from the F.D.A. to the S.E.C. — that regulate much of American economic life have long been the targets of Republican criticism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Joe Coscarelli
title: Man Who Shot the Rapper Nipsey Hussle Is Convicted of Murder
description: A jury found Eric R. Holder Jr. guilty of first-degree murder for the 2019 killing of Hussle, an artist who devoted his adult life to championing his South Los Angeles neighborhood.
content: LOS ANGELES — More than three years after the fatal shooting of the rapper Nipsey Hussle, whose 2019 killing in front of the local clothing store he owned scarred the South Los Angeles neighborhood he had devoted his adult life to championing, a jury on Wednesday found Eric R. Holder Jr. guilty of first-degree murder in the case. The verdict closes a painful chapter in recent hip-hop history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Creature Comforts
description: Animal life may not be the first thing that comes to mind about New York City, but look and you’ll find it.
content: In my first years in New York, summer, for me, always started with the seals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Promised to Stay Above the Fray, but Democrats Want a Fighter
description: President Biden’s measured approach at a time of political tumult has left him struggling to inspire his supporters and allies to action.
content: WASHINGTON — Forty-eight hours after a horrific mass shooting on the Fourth of July, President Biden flew to Ohio on Wednesday for a speech on pension plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Tess Felder
title: More officials resign, including a minister who defended Johnson two days earlier.
description: A growing number of officials in Boris Johnson’s government are stepping down, adding to the pressure on the prime minister.
content: LONDON — Britain’s minister for children and families resigned on Wednesday morning, becoming the latest in a growing exodus of officials from the scandal-engulfed government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Hello, Goodbye and Everything in Between’ Review: Break Cute?
description: In this adaptation of Jennifer E. Smith’s young adult novel, two high school seniors agree to split up in a year. Will they honor their pact?
content: Early in the teenage-targeted romantic comedy “Hello, Goodbye, and Everything in Between” — based on Jennifer E. Smith’s young adult novel — a senior, Aidan (Jordan Fisher), performs a Ferris Bueller-like rendition of “Twist and Shout” at a house party to the amusement of a new classmate, Clare (Talia Ryder). Before the evening ends, the two have shared a kiss and make a pact to dissolve whatever relationship might follow in a year’s time. (Having seen the downside of her divorced parents’ high school romance, Clare insists and Aidan signs on.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: In Your Enthusiasm for Planting, Don’t Forget About the Trees
description: Trees can take a lot of punishment, but they have their limits. Here’s how to work around them safely.
content: If trees could talk, they’d probably start by saying, “Enough with the insults already.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Lets Juul Appeal Ban and Stay on the Market During a Review
description: The F.D.A. has suspended its order to stop the company from selling its vaping products.
content: The Food and Drug Administration has decided to allow Juul Labs’ vaping products to stay on the market temporarily, citing “scientific issues” that warrant a review of the agency’s ruling last month to ban the company’s e-cigarettes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘Son of Elsewhere,’ a Funny and Frank Story About Life After a Big Move
description: In his “memoir in pieces,” Elamin Abdelmahmoud writes about the years after he and his family emigrated from Sudan to Canada when he was 12.
content: As an immigrant kid in Kingston, one of the whitest cities in Canada, Elamin Abdelmahmoud learned pretty quickly that he was Black. At first this was news to him: He had spent the first 12 years of his life in Sudan identifying as Arab — when he thought about his identity at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: These New Breastfeeding Guidelines Ignore the Reality of Many American Moms
description: On the heels of Roe being overturned, a formula shortage and the failure to pass the PUMP Act, the recommendation to breastfeed for “two years or beyond” was ill timed.
content: Last week, the American Academy of Pediatrics released an updated policy statement on breastfeeding that suggested increasing the duration of breastfeeding to two years or more from one year or more. As my Times colleague Catherine Pearson explained, this is the first update to the breastfeeding recommendations in a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Wall St.’s Great Crypto Escape
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 6, 2022.
content: “Pandora’s box is opened — you can’t close it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Reese
title: A Neurologist’s Tips to Protect Your Memory
description: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
content: As we age, our memory declines. This is an ingrained assumption for many of us; however, according to neuroscientist Dr. Richard Restak, a neurologist and clinical professor at George Washington Hospital University School of Medicine and Health, decline is not inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Brara
title: Art School Confidential
description: David Salle, Miranda July, Mariko Mori and others talk about their experiences attending (or leaving or forgoing) the academy.
content: Whether or not one decides to go to art school depends on a great number of factors, including, of course, one’s ability to get in, which sometimes has more to do with luck than with talent, not to mention an awareness that art school even exists and that being an artist is a viable option, which for many people, especially those from disadvantaged communities, can be a discovery in itself. This aside, it’s usually a matter of weighing the benefits — namely training and time and space to think and make work — against the often literal and sometimes substantial costs. There’s no clear answer, but what is clear is that art school alone cannot make you an artist, or shield you from self-doubt, uncertainty or rejection. Perhaps for this reason, some artists are most grateful for the sense of community provided by those they met while students — often a classmate or teacher becomes a lifelong friend, collaborator or mentor, someone who shows up regardless of the state of the other person’s career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Bradford Freeman, Last of the ‘Band of Brothers,’ Dies at 97
description: The exploits of his World War II paratroop company were chronicled in a best-selling book and then in an acclaimed HBO mini-series.
content: Bradford Freeman, the last survivor of the World War II paratroop company whose combat exploits were described in the best-selling book and subsequent mini-series “Band of Brothers,” died on Sunday in Columbus, Miss. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove and Robert Gebeloff
title: The Shrinking of the Middle-Class Neighborhood
description: Americans are increasingly living in areas that are either much richer or much poorer than the regional norm.
content: NASHVILLE — When Ashley Broadnax thinks of the East Nashville neighborhood she grew up in during the ’90s, the images that rush in have a modest, middle-class tinge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Go Off in Two Directions
description: Sam Koperwas and Jeff Chen perform a bit of prestidigitation.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Sam Koperwas, who is making his first appearance in the New York Times Crossword today, and to Jeff Chen, who is making his 133rd. Incredibly, this is also Mr. Chen’s 88th collaboration, and Mr. Koperwas is Mr. Chen’s 50th collaborator. That kind of dedication to mentorship of new constructors is unparalleled among New York Times Crossword constructors — the person with the next-most collaborators has 20 fewer than Mr. Chen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: 80 million Americans are under heat warnings or advisories.
description: Overnight temperatures won’t drop off during the heat wave as much as usual, raising concerns about the health of vulnerable people.
content: Temperatures across the middle parts of the United States were “dangerously high” on Wednesday, the National Weather Service warned, as another heat wave took hold. And it won’t end soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Stanley Reed
title: Europe, Facing Energy Shortages, Moves to Shore Up Providers
description: Berlin and Paris are preparing bailouts as Europe braces for further cuts to gas supplies next week and economists warn of a recession.
content: BERLIN — Leaders in Europe, facing their worst energy crisis in decades, are taking extraordinary steps to secure supplies for winter amid fears of fuel shortages and near-record electricity and natural gas prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Secures Deal for Cipollone to Be Interviewed
description: The former White House counsel pushed back on President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election and was in the West Wing to witness his actions on Jan. 6, 2021.
content: Pat A. Cipollone, the White House counsel to President Donald J. Trump who repeatedly fought Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election, has reached a deal to be interviewed by Friday before the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack, according to people familiar with the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: They Loved Volcanoes and Each Other
description: A new documentary examines the work and lives of the French volcanologists Katia and Maurice Krafft, helped mightily by their own magnificent footage.
content: In “Fire of Love,” the voice-over quotes Maurice and Katia Krafft’s feelings about the risks in their line of work: exploring and filming volcanoes. “I prefer an intense and short life to a monotonous, long one,” Maurice wrote. Katia acknowledged the danger but said that in the moment, she didn’t care at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Fire of Love’ Review: A Volcanic Romance
description: Sara Dosa’s new documentary chronicles the lives and deaths of the French scientists Katia and Maurice Krafft.
content: The subjects of Sara Dosa’s new documentary “Fire of Love” are Maurice and Katia Krafft, married French scientists who devoted their lives to the study of volcanoes. Really, though, it might be more accurate to describe the couple, who died in a volcanic eruption in 1991, as co-directors, since they were the ones who captured the most arresting images in this curious and haunting film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: U.S. pharmacists receive permission from the F.D.A. to prescribe Pfizer’s Covid pills.
description: Previously, only doctors, nurses or physician assistants were allowed to prescribe the treatment, known as Paxlovid.
content: The Food and Drug Administration added pharmacists on Wednesday to the list of health care professionals who are allowed to prescribe Pfizer’s pills for treating Covid-19. The move, aimed at making it easier for patients to get the drug, will significantly increase the number of prescribers who can order the treatment, known as Paxlovid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: N.Y.C. Ferry System Lost Track of $224 Million, Audit Finds
description: The city’s comptroller, which conducted the audit, said that the semi-independent city agency that runs the ferry network had made decisions resulting in millions of dollars in unnecessary expenses.
content: The agency in charge of running New York City’s ferry system failed to report nearly a quarter-billion dollars in costs during the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio, the city comptroller announced on Wednesday in a 50-page audit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Roe Is Dead. How Will Democrats and the G.O.P. Evolve Without It?
description: Michelle Goldberg and Ross Douthat on what comes next for Democrats and Republicans.
content: For nearly 50 years, the issue of abortion has driven voters of all persuasions to the polls. But now that Roe v. Wade has been overturned and the question of reproductive rights has been returned to the states, America’s political parties are going to have to figure out how to metabolize that energy in the years ahead. To discuss what comes next for Democrats and Republicans alike, host Jane Coaston is joined by Times Opinion columnists Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg. As colleagues, they’ve been debating abortion with each other, on this podcast and in the pages of the paper, for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: China Seeks to Pre-Empt Sanctions in Case of Taiwan Clash, F.B.I. Chief Says
description: Looking ahead to a possible conflict, Beijing wants to shield itself from the kind of economic penalties levied against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, the F.B.I. director says.
content: LONDON — Learning from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, China is looking for ways to protect its economy from the threat of international sanctions should a confrontation over Taiwan occur, “a clue” to Beijing’s view of what the future holds, the F.B.I. director said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson quickly fills the two cabinet vacancies in an effort to stabilize a government in crisis.
description: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved quickly to plug the holes in his cabinet caused by Tuesday’s resignations of two senior ministers, including the critical job of chancellor of the Exchequer, which went to Nadhim Zahawi, who had been the education secretary.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved quickly to plug the holes in his cabinet caused by Tuesday’s resignations of two senior ministers, including the critical job of chancellor of the Exchequer, which went to Nadhim Zahawi, who had been the education secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Is ‘Face Blindness’ Real?
description: Brad Pitt has said he might have prosopagnosia, which affects his ability to recognize people. Here’s what to know about the condition.
content: The actor Brad Pitt said in a recent interview that he has prosopagnosia, a rare neurological disorder commonly referred to as face blindness. While Mr. Pitt, 58, has never been formally diagnosed with the condition, he said in an interview with GQ that he had struggled for years to recognize people’s faces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Ben Protess
title: Real Estate Firm Tied to Trump Inquiry Fined for Contempt of Court
description: The firm, Cushman & Wakefield, was ordered to pay $10,000 a day until it complies with a subpoena. It appraised several Trump properties that are at the center of the New York attorney general’s investigation.
content: A New York state judge on Tuesday held one of the world’s largest real estate firms — which appraised several of former President Donald J. Trump’s properties — in contempt of court in connection with a civil investigation into whether he falsely inflated the value of his assets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Willie Lee Morrow, Barber Who Popularized the Afro Pick, Dies at 82
description: He built an empire around hair care products aimed at African American consumers, including a softener that inspired the Jheri curl.
content: Willie Lee Morrow, a son of Alabama sharecroppers who built a business empire around hair care products aimed at African American consumers, among them a comb designed to work with the natural styles that exploded in popularity in the 1960s — a tool he called the Afro Tease, but which came to be known as the Afro pick — died on June 22 at his home in San Diego. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Biden administration seeks to curb student loan interest and simplify relief programs.
description: New rules would undo Trump administration actions and give borrowers an easier path through loan forgiveness programs.
content: The Education Department is preparing a raft of new rules for federal student loans that aims to expand access to various relief programs and undo changes made during the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Ham
title: With Housing Limited, a Gecko and a Possum Family Became Roommates
description: They won’t eat each other, and the family of marsupials does not seem to mind that the lizard is using them for warmth.
content: When Alex Hams, a land conservation manager at Bush Heritage Australia, was giving a tour to visiting scientists and volunteers in mid-June, he got more than he bargained for. He opened the lid of a nest box for western pygmy possums at the Monjebup Nature Reserve, which his organization manages in southwestern Australia. There, among the leaves, he found not just a family of pygmy possums, but also a small, orange-eyed lizard known as a western spiny-tailed gecko.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Almer Durston, Campbell Robertson and Dan Simmons
title: Before Shooting, Highland Park Was Considered Chicago’s ‘Mayberry’
description: Intended from the start as an oasis, the suburb is struggling to comprehend its new identity as the latest site of a mass shooting
content: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — It was intended, from its very origins, to be an oasis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Comey and McCabe, Who Infuriated Trump, Both Faced Intensive I.R.S. Audits
description: The former F.B.I. director and his deputy, both of whom former President Donald J. Trump wanted prosecuted, were selected for a rare audit program that the tax agency says is random.
content: Among tax lawyers, the most invasive type of random audit carried out by the I.R.S. is known, only partly jokingly, as “an autopsy without the benefit of death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 2: On ‘Why Strangers Are Good for Us’
description: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Sophene Avedissian, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions
content: We received 815 entries from students from around the world for the second week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Sophene,  as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A Prized Recruit Shows the Shoe Circuit Is Not the Only Path
description: Xavier Booker, in an unusual move, is sidestepping the carnival of tournaments put on by shoe companies to showcase elite men’s basketball players.
content: LAS VEGAS — Few could have foreseen Xavier Booker, who as a sophomore barely got off his high school team’s bench, in his current position: being scrutinized by N.B.A. scouts and recruited by Kansas, Kentucky, Gonzaga, Duke, Michigan State, Michigan, Indiana and a cadre of others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Job openings eased, in a sign of the cooling labor market.
description: The number of U.S. positions available was 11.3 million in May, the second straight monthly decline.
content: Employers became slightly less desperate for workers in May as job openings declined for the second straight month from a record high in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How to Prepare for California’s Wildfire Season
description: Tips for readying your home and packing your emergency bag.
content: By many accounts, this year’s fire season will be brutal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Biden Speaks to Cherelle Griner About Her Wife’s Detention in Russia
description: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris told Cherelle Griner they would pursue “every avenue” to bring her wife, Brittney Griner, home from Russia.
content: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris spoke on Wednesday with Cherelle Griner, the wife of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner. Brittney Griner has been detained in Russia on drug charges since February, and her trial began Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Funeral Home Operator Pleads Guilty in ‘Illegal Body Part Scheme’
description: Megan Hess, who pleaded guilty to mail fraud, sold body parts without families’ consent in a business she operated with her mother, officials said.
content: The operator of a Colorado funeral home who was accused of stealing body parts and selling them to medical and scientific buyers, making hundreds of thousands of dollars in what the authorities called an “illegal body part scheme,” pleaded guilty to mail fraud on Tuesday, the Justice Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: A Feminist, Neorealist, Communist Film, and a Plain Great Movie
description: “One Way or Another,” from 1974, is a class-conscious love story involving a macho worker and a well-to-do schoolteacher in Cuba.
content: Dialectical from opening title to final image, “One Way or Another” — the first and only feature by the Afro-Cuban director Sara Gómez — introduces itself as “a film about real people, and some fictitious ones.” That’s one way to describe this deft mixture of cinéma vérité, ethnographic documentary, feminist social realism and class-conscious revolutionary romance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith, Campbell Robertson, Frances Robles and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Highland Park Shooting Reveals Limits of Illinois’s Gun Restrictions
description: Legislators and gun control advocates are asking how the 21-year-old suspect was able to buy several weapons despite alarming police encounters and relatively strict state laws.
content: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — On Monday morning, Julie Morrison, an Illinois state senator, was sitting in the back of a convertible, waving to Fourth of July paradegoers, her grandchildren walking alongside the car. Ms. Morrison, a Democrat, had made combating gun violence a priority in her legislative career, and had been the chief sponsor of the state’s “red flag” law, which set up a system in which guns can be taken from someone found to be dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Photos: Battling the Electra fire in Northern California.
description: The wildfire is burning 50 miles southeast of Sacramento in the Sierra Nevada foothills
content: A wildfire burning 50 miles southeast of Sacramento in the Sierra Nevada foothills had exploded by Wednesday to 3,900 acres, prompting evacuation orders for thousands of people and injuring an emergency medical worker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maham Javaid
title: Most Americans Say Life Is Starting to Return to Pre-Covid Normal, a Poll Shows
description: In the survey, 54 percent of adults said their lives are somewhat the same.
content: Most Americans say their lives are at least approaching prepandemic normalcy, according to a recent study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Somini Sengupta
title: Europe Calls Gas and Nuclear Energy ‘Green’
description: Critics say the decision is likely to reverberate beyond Europe’s borders and hamper its efforts to lead the global climate negotiations.
content: In a landmark vote for Europe’s climate and energy policies, the European Parliament on Wednesday endorsed labeling some gas and nuclear energy projects as “green,” allowing them access to hundreds of billions of euros in cheap loans and even state subsidies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Her ‘Chagall’ Is Headed for the Trash. How’s That for Caveat Emptor?
description: Stephanie Clegg paid $90,000 for a Marc Chagall painting at a Sotheby’s auction in 1994. It was reappraised for $100,000 in 2008. Now an expert panel in France wants to destroy it as a fake.
content: The question of whether a valuable artwork is genuine can be surprisingly fluid, changing over time based on evolving and sometime competing evaluations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: The decline of Yandex, a Russia tech giant, reflects the domestic troubles stirred by the invasion.
description: What a difference a war makes.
content: What a difference a war makes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.H. Miller
title: With a Culture War Raging Around Education, Where Does Art School Fit In?
description: T’s 2022 Art issue looks at how art is taught — if it can be taught at all — and what the future holds for aspiring talents.
content: Of all the areas of modern life that have been disrupted as of late, arguably none have suffered quite so absurdly as America’s system of education. Even to merely list, in oblique terms, a few of the basic problems of schools of all kinds in this country is to stare into the maw of a culture in decline. One major political party has decided the right to own semiautomatic rifles is more important than the lives of children, while the other has done little to counter it; state and federal policy has left young, economically vulnerable adults mired in unnecessary debt that many have no hope of repaying; increasingly mainstreamed extremists want to police behavior among students and teachers and rewrite history books in their favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Latin of Software Code Is Thriving
description: Next time you laugh at musty old tech, remember that new technologies are often built on it.
content: Caitlin Mooney is 24 years old and infatuated with technology that dates to the age of Sputnik.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: A Year Since a President’s Murder, Haitians Keep Waiting to Hit Rock Bottom
description: In the year since President Jovenel Moïse was killed, the country’s despair has deepened. Gangs now vie with the government for control.
content: The warring gangs took over several neighborhoods around Port-au-Prince weeks ago, going door to door, raping women and girls, killing the men, beheading many of the adults and then forcing the newly orphaned children into their ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Explosion Destroys Mysterious Monument in Georgia, Authorities Say
description: For more than four decades, the Georgia Guidestones near Elberton Ga., have been an enigma. On Wednesday, the authorities said, “unknown individuals” destroyed a large part of the structure.
content: An explosive device that “unknown individuals” detonated early Wednesday destroyed a granite monument in Georgia that was built under mysterious circumstances more than four decades ago and promoted by state officials as “America’s Stonehenge,” the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Will Nadal Be Ready for His Wimbledon Semifinal and Kyrgios?
description: Nadal struggled with an abdominal injury in his grueling quarterfinal victory over Taylor Fritz, a rising American star who pushed Nadal to five sets.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — It was Wednesday evening on Centre Court, and Rafael Nadal was back in the semifinals of Wimbledon after proving once again that his threshold for pain and ability to improvise under duress are far beyond the norm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Zipo-zenkosi Ncokazi
title: Mass Funeral Deepens Mystery: Why Did 21 South African Teens Die in Tavern?
description: Survivors of the tragedy last month recounted in interviews the presence of a mysterious gas and then a crush to escape. Officials say the stampede didn’t kill them.
content: EAST LONDON, South Africa — Before he passed out amid the crush of bodies, Simbongile Mtsweni gasped for air as a gas that felt like fire crept into his nose and lungs. “When I came to,” he said, “I was on the second floor and started vomiting when I realized I was lying next to dead people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Milov
title: The End of the Illusion That Smoking Is a Choice
description: An F.D.A. proposal to lower nicotine levels in cigarettes could save millions of lives.
content: The Food and Drug Administration recently proposed lowering the nicotine content in cigarettes to less addictive levels. If adopted, this regulation would finally test one of the tobacco industry’s favorite claims: that smoking is a choice. Portraying smoking as a willful, personal decision has long allowed tobacco companies to promote cigarettes even while acknowledging their deadly risks. But the paradigm of individual choice has also guided cigarette regulation, ironically strengthening the industry’s key talking point — until now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: ‘The Golden Age of Thrifting Is Over’
description: A glut of fast fashion has made its way into local thrift stores, making it hard for women who have been purchasing secondhand for decades to find quality garments they can wear.
content: Tina Koeppe grew up thrifting. When she was younger, she would spend weekends going to thrift stores with her mother, hunting for unique trinkets and garments but mostly looking for quality items to fit into her family’s tight budget. Now in her 40s and with a daughter of her own, Ms. Koeppe has carried the thriftiness of her youth into adulthood. Most of the furniture and décor in her home came from thrift stores. All of her clothes, except for her socks and underwear, were purchased secondhand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Aggeler
title: When a Bra Won’t Cut It
description: For outfits that call for more than your typical undergarments, there’s tape.
content: Human beings are outliers in the animal kingdom in having permanently enlarged breasts — which is either a huge boon or a crushing burden, depending on how you look at it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: The Thirst for Merch
description: Virgil Abloh fans, art lovers and resellers flocked to the opening of “Figures of Speech” at the Brooklyn Museum, hoping to take home a piece of fashion history.
content: On Friday morning, a cloudless sky stretched above the Brooklyn Museum. As the sun marked the arrival of a sweltering July, clusters of people lined up an hour before opening to be the first ones inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laila Lalami
title: Tell Me if You’ve Heard This Story Before
description: The deaths of migrants in Melilla, a Spanish enclave in northern Morocco, are gut-wrenching.
content: The border guard stood beside a small, cinder-block building, squinting in the sunlight. From where I sat in the back seat of my parents’ old Renault, he seemed tall and a little scary. But with only a quick look inside, he waved us through on our day trip to Melilla, a Spanish enclave in northern Morocco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cleyvis Natera
title: For Black Girls, Womanhood Comes Too Early
description: In Mecca Jamilah Sullivan’s debut novel, an 8-year-old girl in Harlem is forced to change her body to fit someone else’s standard.
content: What is a child’s body worth when it is big, Black and female — when it is under constant demand to be something other than what it naturally is? In Mecca Jamilah Sullivan’s achingly beautiful coming-of-age debut novel, “Big Girl,” this body carries the weight of an entire neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Directing the Beatles Was Just One Part of His Long and Winding Career
description: The filmmaker Michael Lindsay-Hogg, who attracted some social media scrutiny after his appearance in Peter Jackson’s “Get Back,” finds peace in New York’s Hudson Valley.
content: HUDSON, N.Y. — Of course I wanted to talk with Michael Lindsay-Hogg about the Beatles. Everyone wants to talk with him about the Beatles, especially since his star turn in “Get Back,” Peter Jackson’s epic documentary, which debuted last fall on Disney+.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Allies Abandon Boris Johnson Amid Latest Scandal, but He Vows to Go On
description: A wave of resignations — more than 50 by Thursday — and calls for him to step down showed the prime minister’s support within his Conservative Party melting away, but he remained defiant.
content: LONDON — His support crumbling, his government in disarray, his alibis exhausted, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain tried frantically on Wednesday to salvage his position, even as a delegation of cabinet colleagues traveled to Downing Street to plead with their scandal-scarred leader to step down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Economy Is Already Cooling, So Why Is the Fed Dousing It With Cold Water?
description: The bank’s aggressive rate-raising could lead to a recession.
content: The Federal Reserve would do well to remember the old saying: Two wrongs don’t make a right. Its first wrong was ignoring inflation. The second — the one it’s committing right now — is fighting inflation too hard.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: These are the letters that James B. Comey and Andrew G. McCabe received from the I.R.S.
content: These are the letters that James B. Comey and Andrew G. McCabe received from the I.R.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Matiash
title: The Latest on Abortion in the States
description: In the aftermath of the Supreme Court striking down Roe v. Wade, there has been a flurry of activity in the states as officials move to prohibit or expand abortion access.
content: In the aftermath of the Supreme Court striking down Roe v. Wade, there has been a flurry of activity in the states as officials move to prohibit or expand abortion access.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A 19th-Century Stone Villa on Majorca
description: This eight-bedroom manor on the Spanish island of Majorca, with a mix of modernist, Majorcan and French styles, is on the market for $2.7 million.
content: This eight-bedroom manor on the Spanish island of Majorca, with a mix of modernist, Majorcan and French styles, is on the market for $2.7 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Gardiner, N.Y.
description: The 50-mile Shawangunk Ridge is just one reason New Yorkers are flocking to this Ulster County town, which is also prized for its wide-open spaces.
content: The 50-mile Shawangunk Ridge is just one reason New Yorkers are flocking to this Ulster County town, which is also prized for its wide-open spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

title: $830,000 Homes in Ohio, Connecticut and the District of Columbia
description: A Spanish-style house in Oakwood, a 1764 Colonial in Lyme and a three-bedroom rowhouse in Washington.
content: A Spanish-style house in Oakwood, a 1764 Colonial in Lyme and a three-bedroom rowhouse in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: The Rise of the Professional-Athlete Podcast
description: Does getting game analyses straight from the source take away some of the magic?
content: Postgame analysis is an integral part of the sports experience. After the final buzzer, fans take to the internet, television and radio to learn what their teams did to win (made their shots, played defense) or lose (missed their shots, didn’t play defense). Even the sports-averse can easily picture what this traditionally looks like: four men (maybe three men and one woman), seated behind a long desk, offering sage insights like “I thought they struggled with catching the ball,” to solemn nods of agreement. And yet, for the entirety of the recently concluded N.B.A. Finals, won by the Golden State Warriors over the Boston Celtics, this kind of analysis was also delivered by a more intimate source: the Warriors’ own Draymond Green, who, following every contest, left the court to analyze the game he’d just played, as the host of a podcast called “The Draymond Green Show.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: The Shape-Shifting Sherlock Holmes, Now Playing the Villain
description: The world’s first consulting detective has appeared in many disguises, including clergyman, sailor and old woman. Now, in a new podcast, he is cast as a monster.
content: Sherlock Holmes was born, magnifying glass in hand, in the 1887 edition of Beeton’s Christmas Annual. In the first chapter of that entry, Arthur Conan Doyle’s “A Study in Scarlet,” a character described Holmes this way: “He is a little queer in his ideas — an enthusiast in some branches of science. As far as I know he is a decent fellow enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: ‘I Don’t Want to Help Him’: Joe Rogan Says He Refused Trump as a Podcast Guest
description: The commentator, who is no stranger to controversy, claimed he had declined several times to have the former president on his influential podcast on Spotify.
content: Joe Rogan, whose contrarian views on vaccines and political conspiracy theories have made him popular with many supporters of former President Donald J. Trump, revealed that he had declined to host Mr. Trump on his influential podcast several times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Have a Pizza Party
description: Wednesdays can be rough. Order delivery and garnish the pie just how you like it.
content: Good morning. I’d wager I cook more than your average newspaper editor. I enjoy feeding my family and appreciate the break it offers me from thinking about facts and figures, stories and consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 6, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 6, 2022.
content: An article on Monday about American Special Operations veterans training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia mischaracterized the group that helps evacuate Americans from Ukraine. It is a nonprofit organization, not a volunteer group.
source.name: The New York Times

title: America at 246: An Unvarnished Look
description: Several Americans and a foreigner weigh in on the state of America today. Also: Legal, safer cannabis.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
